metadata.titleEn: Meteorological observation data at grassland site of Ngoring Lake basin from 2017 to 2020
metadata.description: This data set is the conventional meteorological observation data of the Ngoring Lake Grassland Observation site (GS) in the source region of the Yellow River from 2017 to 2020, obtained by using Kipp&Zonen CNR4, Vaisala HMP155A, PTB110 and other instruments, with a time resolution of half an hour.  Mainly include wind speed, wind direction, temperature, relative humidity（specific humidity in 2020）, air pressure, downward short-wave radiation, downward long-wave radiation, precipitation.
metadata.instructions: Data were obtained using Kipp&Zonen CNR4, Vaisala HMP155A, PTB110 and other instruments

background: Thousands of lakes on the Tibetan Plateau (TP) play a critical role in the regional water cycle, weather, and climate. However, the characteristics of the lake-atmosphere interaction over the high-altitude lakes are still unclear, which inhibits model development and the accurate simulation of lake climate effects. The Yellow River (YR) is the fifth-longest river in the world and the “lifeblood” of northern China. The source region of the Yellow River (SRYR), with an area of 12.2 ×104 km2, is the most important runoff-producing area for the YR, which accounts for only 16.4% of the YR basin area, but provides approximately 38% runoff. Sometimes called “China's Water Tower”, the SRYR is considered to be an "extremely sensitive region" to climate change. Lakes are a sentinel of climate change, which is a significant local climate driver due to the large thermal inertia and surface area. Ngoring Lake and Gyaring Lake in the SRYR, each at an elevation exceeding 4200 m above sea level, comprise the highest large fresh lakes in the TP. They are in the transition region of westerlies and the Asian monsoon climate and are sensitive to changes in atmospheric circulation. Three land-surface process observation sites (lake, grassland, and lakeside) have been established successively since 2010, helping to fill in the gap of long-term in-situ observations of lake-atmosphere interactions in the freshwater and outflow lakes in the TP.
research objective: Based on this, we hope more characteristics related to lake–atmosphere interactions on the TP will be explored, and more suitable lake models will be established and improved.
methods: Before setting up the observation system, we calibrated the instruments and then used these instruments to determine site locations and conduct observations. For example, the ultrasonic virtual temperature is converted to air temperature, and corrections for time lag compensation, spike and trend removal, and coordinate rotation were made for all original 10-Hz data. The Webb-Pearman-Leuning density correction is applied to the water vapor fluxes. Moreover, the data with automatic gain control values greater than 70 are removed.
dataset: This study presents an eight-year (2012–19), half-hourly, observation-based dataset related to lake–atmosphere interactions composed of three sites. The observations contain the basic meteorological elements, surface radiation, eddy covariance system, soil temperature, and moisture (for land). The dataset is available at National Cryosphere Desert Data Center and Science Data Bank.

Disjunctive.Question: Is the data collection method for lake-atmosphere interactions on the Tibetan Plateau largely based on in-situ observations, remote sensing, or a combination of both?
Are the instruments used for collecting meteorological data in the Yellow River source region more likely to be from manufacturers like Kipp&Zonen, Vaisala, or other vendors?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the instruments used for collecting meteorological data at the observation sites in the Tibetan Plateau?
Where can datasets related to lake-atmosphere interactions on the Tibetan Plateau be accessed?
Concept Completion.Answer: National Cryosphere Desert Data Center and Science Data Bank

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to observe lake-atmosphere interactions on the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to observe lake-atmosphere interactions on the Tibetan Plateau involves setting up observation systems with calibrated instruments to determine site locations and conduct observations. This includes converting ultrasonic virtual temperature to air temperature and making corrections for time lag compensation, spike and trend removal, and coordinate rotation.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific features of the meteorological observations conducted at the grassland observation points in the source region of the Yellow River?
Feature Specification.Answer: wind speed, wind direction, air temperature, relative humidity, specific humidity, atmospheric pressure, downward shortwave radiation, downward longwave radiation, precipitation, half-hour time resolution

Feature Specification.Question: What are the data processing techniques employed to ensure accuracy in the lake-atmosphere interaction dataset?
Feature Specification.Answer: calibrating instruments, converting ultrasonic virtual temperature to air temperature, time lag compensation, spike and trend removal, coordinate rotation, Webb-Pearman-Leuning density correction, removal of data with automatic gain control values greater than 70

Quantification.Question: What is the time resolution used for data collection at the Ngoring Lake and Gyaring Lake observation sites?
How many years of observation data are available for the lake–atmosphere interactions dataset collected at the three sites on the Tibetan Plateau?
What is the elevation above sea level of the Ngoring Lake and Gyaring Lake, which are part of the lake–atmosphere interaction study on the Tibetan Plateau?

Definition.Question: What is the 'Webb-Pearman-Leuning density correction' in the context of data processing for atmospheric observations?
Definition.Answer: The 'Webb-Pearman-Leuning density correction' is a method used in the processing of atmospheric observation data to correct for the effect of density fluctuations on measurements of water vapor fluxes, ensuring more accurate data representation.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'eddy covariance system' in meteorological data collection?
Definition.Answer: An 'eddy covariance system' is a technique used in meteorological data collection to measure and calculate vertical turbulent fluxes within the atmosphere, such as heat, water vapor, and carbon dioxide, by analyzing the covariance between fluctuations in vertical wind speed and scalar quantities.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data processing techniques between the half-hourly meteorological dataset and the eight-year lake-atmosphere interaction dataset?
Comparison.Answer: The half-hourly meteorological dataset involves regular data collection without specified data processing techniques in the description, while the eight-year lake-atmosphere interaction dataset includes detailed data processing such as time lag compensation, spike and trend removal, coordinate rotation, and Webb-Pearman-Leuning density correction for water vapor fluxes.

Interpretation.Question: How can half-hourly meteorological and radiation data from high-altitude lakes be used to improve understanding of lake-atmosphere interactions?
Interpretation.Answer: The half-hourly meteorological and radiation data collected provide insights into the complex dynamics of lake-atmosphere interactions, which are crucial for developing more accurate lake models. These observations help fill the gap in long-term in-situ data and can be used to explore the influence of lakes on regional climate, especially in areas sensitive to changes in atmospheric circulation.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in calibrating instruments for precise high-altitude meteorological observations, and how can these challenges be addressed in data collection?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include ensuring accuracy in high-altitude conditions and the need for specific corrections like time lag compensation, spike and trend removal, and coordinate rotation. Addressing these challenges involves thorough calibration of instruments before deployment and applying advanced correction techniques such as the Webb-Pearman-Leuning density correction for water vapor fluxes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the necessity for calibration of instruments prior to setting up observation systems in high-altitude lake-atmosphere interaction studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Calibration of instruments is necessary to ensure accurate data collection in high-altitude environments, where variations in atmospheric pressure, temperature, and other conditions can affect instrument readings. This step is crucial to accurately convert ultrasonic virtual temperature to air temperature and apply corrections for time lag, spikes, trends, and coordinate rotations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need to remove data with automatic gain control values greater than 70 in meteorological observations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Data with automatic gain control values greater than 70 are removed to filter out unreliable measurements that can introduce noise or inaccuracies in the dataset. High gain control values may indicate instrument saturation or other anomalies that compromise data quality, necessitating their exclusion from analysis.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What necessitates the use of the Webb-Pearman-Leuning density correction in water vapor flux measurements?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The Webb-Pearman-Leuning density correction is applied to water vapor flux measurements to account for errors introduced by density fluctuations in the air. This correction is essential to ensure accurate representation of fluxes in the dataset, as density variations can significantly impact the recorded values, especially in environments with large thermal gradients like high-altitude lakes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using half-hourly observation-based datasets on enhancing the understanding of lake-atmosphere interactions on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using half-hourly observation-based datasets could lead to a deeper understanding of lake-atmosphere interactions due to the detailed temporal resolution, which helps in exploring more characteristics of these interactions and establishing more suitable lake models.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might calibrating instruments before setting up observation systems influence the accuracy and reliability of collected meteorological data in high-altitude regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Calibrating instruments beforehand ensures that observations are accurate and reliable by correcting for factors like ultrasonic virtual temperature conversion, time lag, spikes, trends, and coordinate rotation, contributing to the overall precision and validity of the collected data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the impact on data quality when applying specific data correction methods such as the Webb-Pearman-Leuning density correction and removing data with high automatic gain control values?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Applying these data correction methods likely improves data quality by ensuring more accurate water vapor flux measurements and filtering out unreliable data, which enhances the dataset's integrity and usability for analyzing meteorological phenomena.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary goals of collecting meteorological data from grassland observation sites near high-altitude lakes on the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goals are to explore more characteristics related to lake-atmosphere interactions on the Tibetan Plateau and to establish and improve more suitable lake models.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to implement rigorous calibration and correction techniques in data collection systems observing lake-atmosphere interactions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Rigorous calibration and correction techniques are important to ensure accurate data collection, such as converting ultrasonic virtual temperature to air temperature and applying corrections for time lag compensation, spike and trend removal, and coordinate rotation, which are crucial for understanding lake-atmosphere interactions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What drives the need for long-term in-situ observations of lake-atmosphere interactions in the freshwater and outflow lakes on the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The need is driven by the critical role of lakes in the regional water cycle, weather, and climate, as well as their sensitivity to climate change, making them significant local climate drivers due to their large thermal inertia and surface area.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instruments and calibration steps are necessary to accurately collect meteorological data in high-altitude lake regions like those on the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Before setting up the observation system, instruments such as Kipp&Zonen CNR4, Vaisala HMP155A, and PTB110 are calibrated. The calibration involves converting ultrasonic virtual temperature to air temperature and applying corrections for time lag compensation, spike and trend removal, and coordinate rotation for all original 10-Hz data. Additionally, the Webb-Pearman-Leuning density correction is applied to water vapor fluxes, and data with automatic gain control values greater than 70 are removed.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are long-term, in-situ observations of lake-atmosphere interactions conducted in remote, high-altitude areas?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Three land-surface process observation sites (lake, grassland, and lakeside) have been established since 2010 for conducting long-term, in-situ observations. These sites help in gathering data related to lake-atmosphere interactions by using a combination of meteorological instruments and data processing techniques to ensure accuracy and reliability over extended periods.

Enablement.Question: What instruments and calibration techniques are essential for enabling accurate meteorological data collection in high-altitude lake regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of instruments like Kipp&Zonen CNR4, Vaisala HMP155A, and PTB110, along with calibration techniques such as correcting for time lag compensation, spike and trend removal, and coordinate rotation, are essential for accurate data collection in these regions.

Enablement.Question: How do site location determinations and instrument setups contribute to the effective observation of lake-atmosphere interactions?
Enablement.Answer: Determining site locations and setting up instruments based on calibrated measurements and ensuring the removal of data with high automatic gain control values contribute to effective observation of lake-atmosphere interactions.

Enablement.Question: Which data correction methods are significant in enhancing the reliability of water vapor flux measurements in meteorological datasets?
Enablement.Answer: The Webb-Pearman-Leuning density correction is significant in enhancing the reliability of water vapor flux measurements, ensuring that the data is accurate and reliable.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in accurately simulating lake climate effects over high-altitude lakes on the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: The characteristics of lake-atmosphere interaction over the high-altitude lakes are still unclear, which inhibits model development and accurate simulation of lake climate effects.

Expectation.Question: What might be some reasons for the need to improve lake models on the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: More characteristics related to lake–atmosphere interactions need to be explored to establish and improve more suitable lake models.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise in maintaining long-term in-situ observations for lake-atmosphere interactions in high-altitude regions?
Expectation.Answer: Establishing long-term in-situ observations is challenging, but necessary to fill the gap in data for freshwater and outflow lakes on the Tibetan Plateau.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the data collection techniques used in high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau, considering the challenges of calibration and data correction?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection techniques in high-altitude regions such as the Tibetan Plateau require meticulous calibration of instruments and data correction methods. This includes converting ultrasonic virtual temperature to air temperature, applying time lag compensation, spike and trend removal, coordinate rotation, and the Webb-Pearman-Leuning density correction for water vapor fluxes. These detailed processes suggest a rigorous approach to ensure data accuracy despite environmental challenges.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the potential for expanding meteorological datasets in sensitive climate regions like the Yellow River source area, given the current methodologies?
Judgmental.Answer: Expanding meteorological datasets in sensitive climate regions like the Yellow River source area seems promising, given the existing methodologies that utilize a combination of high-precision instruments and robust data correction techniques. Establishing more observation sites and enhancing data resolution could provide deeper insights into lake-atmosphere interactions and climate change impacts.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how calibration of instruments before data collection impacts the accuracy of meteorological observations.
Assertion.Answer: Before setting up the observation system, instruments are calibrated to ensure that the data collected is accurate. This process helps in correctly converting measurements like the ultrasonic virtual temperature to air temperature and applying necessary corrections such as time lag compensation, spike and trend removal, and coordinate rotation.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the techniques used to correct errors in high-frequency meteorological data collection.
Assertion.Answer: Corrections for errors in high-frequency data include time lag compensation, spike and trend removal, and coordinate rotation. Additionally, the Webb-Pearman-Leuning density correction is applied specifically to water vapor fluxes, and data with automatic gain control values greater than 70 are removed to ensure data quality.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the importance of having multiple observation sites for studying lake-atmosphere interactions.
Assertion.Answer: Having multiple observation sites, such as lake, grassland, and lakeside, is crucial for understanding lake-atmosphere interactions because it allows for comprehensive data collection across different environments. This approach helps fill in gaps in long-term in-situ observations, providing varied data on basic meteorological elements, surface radiation, and soil temperature and moisture.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methodologies used for calibrating observational instruments for accurate data collection in lake-atmosphere interaction studies.
Request/Directive.Answer: Before setting up the observation system, instruments are calibrated, including converting ultrasonic virtual temperature to air temperature and applying corrections for time lag, spike, trend, and coordinate rotations. Additionally, the Webb-Pearman-Leuning density correction is applied to water vapor fluxes, and data with automatic gain control values greater than 70 are removed.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that can be used to study lake–atmosphere interactions on the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: An eight-year, half-hourly observation-based dataset related to lake–atmosphere interactions is available, composed of three sites. This dataset includes basic meteorological elements, surface radiation, eddy covariance system data, soil temperature, and moisture for land. It can be accessed at the National Cryosphere Desert Data Center and Science Data Bank.
